dt.t: your letter … allows me to {wi}infer{/wi} that you are as well as ever

dt.t: this doth {wi}infer{/wi} the zeal I had to see him

pt: Sir Thomas More is the first writer known to have used both {it}infer{/it} and {it}imply{/it} in their approved senses in 1528 (with {it}infer{/it} meaning "to deduce from facts" and {it}imply{/it} meaning "to hint at"). He is also the first to have used {it}infer{/it} in a sense close in meaning to {it}imply{/it} (1533). Both of these uses of {it}infer{/it} coexisted without comment until some time around the end of World War I. Since then, the "indicate" and "hint or suggest" meanings of {it}infer{/it} have been frequently condemned as an undesirable blurring of a useful distinction. The actual blurring has been done by the commentators. The "indicate" sense of {it}infer{/it}, descended from More's use of 1533, does not occur with a personal subject. When objections arose, they were to a use with a personal subject (which is now considered a use of the "suggest, hint" sense of {it}infer{/it}). Since dictionaries did not recognize this use specifically, the objectors assumed that the "indicate" sense was the one they found illogical, even though it had been in respectable use for four centuries. The actual usage condemned was a spoken one never used in logical discourse. At present the condemned "suggest, hint" sense is found in print chiefly in letters to the editor and other informal prose, not in serious intellectual writing. The controversy over the "suggest, hint" sense has apparently reduced the frequency with which the "indicate" sense of {it}infer{/it} is used.

{sc}infer{/sc} {sc}deduce{/sc} {sc}conclude{/sc} {sc}judge{/sc} {sc}gather{/sc} mean to arrive at a mental conclusion. {sc}infer{/sc} implies arriving at a conclusion by reasoning from evidence; if the evidence is slight, the term comes close to {it}surmise{/it}.

pt.t: from that remark, I {it}inferred{/it} that they knew each other

pt: {sc}deduce{/sc} often adds to {sc}infer{/sc} the special implication of drawing a particular inference from a generalization.

pt.t: denied we could {it}deduce{/it} anything important from human mortality

pt: {sc}conclude{/sc} implies arriving at a necessary inference at the end of a chain of reasoning.

pt.t: {it}concluded{/it} that only the accused could be guilty

pt: {sc}judge{/sc} stresses a weighing of the evidence on which a conclusion is based.
{sc}gather{/sc} suggests an intuitive forming of a conclusion from implications.

pt.t: {it}gathered{/it} their desire to be alone without a word

quotes.t: … I {qword}infer{/qword} that Swinburne found an adequate outlet for the creative impulse in his poetry …
Lucy … reseated herself with an alacrity and cheerfulness which seemed to {qword}infer{/qword} that she could taste no greater delight …
May I remark here that although I seem to {qword}infer{/qword} that private communication is an unholy mess of grammatical barbarism,  … such is not my intent …
